name: Hancock Campground
note: Wooded tent and RV sites along the Pemigewasset River.  Campsite decriptions do not specify max RV length.

name: Moosalamoo Campground
note: 19 tent and RV sites.  Max vehicle length 20 feet.

name: Mongaup Pond Campground
note: Located in the Catskills, this campground offers tent and RV sites near a pond ideal for swimming, kayaking, and fishing.

name: North-South Lake Campground
note: The highest-elevation state campground in the Catskills, this site offers tent and RV camping near North and South Lakes.

name: Cataloochee Campground
note: Nestled in a valley surrounded by mountain peaks, this campground offers 27 sites for tents and RVs.

name: Balsam Mountain Campground
note: Surrounded by mountain ranges and streams.  Summer daytime temperatures rarely exceed 70째F (~21째C) and lows may dip to 50째F (10째C).  RV and tent sites plus flush toilets and drinking water are available.  Steep, winding access road.

name: Cardens Bluff Campground
note: Most sites are tent only.  Four sites are available for RVs.

name: Linville Falls Campground
note: Closed for 2025 due to hurricane Helene

name: Julian Price Campground
note: Temporarily closed as of June 2025 due to damage from Hurricane Helene

name: Piney Mountain campsites
note: Potomac-Garrett State Forest, 10 dispersed campsites along Piney Mountain road.  Self-registration kiosk on Piney Mountain road near Sang Run road.  $10 per night.

name: Snaggy Mountain campsites
note: Potomac-Garrett State Forest, 10 dispersed campsites along Snaggy Mountain road between Cranesville road and Sanders lane.  Self-registration kiosk on Snaggy Mountain road near Cranesville road.  $10 per night.

name: Lostland Run campsites
note: Potomac-Garrett State Forest, 5 dispersed campsites along Lostland Run road leading to north branch of Potomac River.  Self-registration kiosk on Lost Land Run road near Potomac Camp road.  $10 per night.

name: Wallman/Laurel Run campsites
note: Potomac-Garrett State Forest, 14 dispersed campsites along Wallman and Laurel Run roads leading to north branch of Potomac River.  Self-registration kiosk at 15 Laurel Run.  $10 per night.

name: Moody Boat Launch campsites
note: Geo Wash Nat'l Forest free boat launch with several campsites.  Last 3.5 miles are gravel.  Located in flood plain so avoid during heavy rain.  Reports that the road has deteriorated and is now narrow with deep ruts.  May be impassable without 4WD.

name: FR92 Roadside Site
note: Alongside FR92 is a narrow lane with two camping places.  The first is accessible to almost any vehicle.  The second would probably require a 4WD.

name: Columbia Furnace Boondock
note: Large gravel lot owned by the forest service. Likely fits 5+ large RVs. Very friendly forest rangers and completely legal. Lots of smaller campsites along the main forest road.

name: Seneca Shadows Campground
note: Seneca Shadows is the newest campground in the Spruce Knob-Seneca Rocks National Recreation Area. Many sites offer outstanding views of the 900 foot Seneca Rocks. This is a modern campground with flush toilets, lantern posts, picnic tables and campfire rings. The large facility has a selection of walk-to tent sites, standard RV sites and tent-only group sites.

name: Lake Buffalo Recreation Area
note: A primitive camping area next to a 22-acre lake stocked with trout, suitable for fishing and kayaking. Limited dispersed sites are available, primarily for tents or small RVs. The area is open from March to November.  Popular with anglers, this quiet retreat is ideal for a long weekend. Nearby Long Run and East Fork of the Greenbrier River offer additional fishing opportunities.

name: Little River Dispersed Camping
note: 15 numbered sites along the Little River, suitable for tents and small to medium RVs. The setting is peaceful with access to the West Fork Rail Trail and fishing opportunities. The narrow gravel road may be tricky for larger rigs.  Very remote with no cell service, ideal for those seeking solitude. Sites fill up on weekends.

name: Cherry Springs State Park Rustic Campground
note: Cherry Springs State Park is nearly as remote and wild today as it was two centuries ago. Its dark skies make it a haven for astronomers. Due to its exceptionally dark skies, Cherry Springs State Park is one of the best places on the eastern seaboard for stargazing and the science of astronomy

name: Watchman Campground
note: Nestled at the base of the iconic Watchman Peak, this campground offers dramatic views of red sandstone cliffs and the Virgin River. The towering formations create a breathtaking backdrop, especially at sunrise or sunset.

name: North Rim Campground
note: Perched on the quieter, less-visited North Rim, this campground provides jaw-dropping vistas of the Grand Canyon’s vast expanse. The elevation and remoteness enhance the sweeping views of the canyon’s layered cliffs.

name: Silver Bell
note: Located near Aspen, this campground frames the iconic Maroon Bells—twin peaks rising above Maroon Lake. The rugged Elk Mountains and golden aspens in fall make it a postcard-worthy spot.

name: Kirk Creek Campground
note: Perched above the Pacific Ocean along the rugged Big Sur coast, this spot offers panoramic views of waves crashing against cliffs. The sunrise over the water is a highlight, with trails leading to redwoods and waterfalls nearby.

name: Many Glacier Campground
note: Surrounded by jagged peaks and Swiftcurrent Lake, this campground boasts stunning views of Glacier’s iconic mountains. The reflective waters and frequent wildlife sightings add to the spectacle.

name: Tuolumne Meadows Campground
note: High in the Sierra Nevada, this campground features sweeping views of granite domes, meadows, and waterfalls. The open landscape showcases Yosemite’s alpine splendor, especially with wildflowers in summer.

name: Kalaloch Campground
note: Overlooking the Pacific Ocean, this campground provides dramatic coastal views from bluff-top sites. Driftwood-strewn beaches and the sound of crashing waves make it a striking spot year-round.

name: Bartlett Cove Campground
note: Tucked along the shores of Glacier Bay, this remote site offers views of icy waters, dense forests, and distant snow-capped peaks. Kayaking reveals even more of the area’s wild beauty.

name: Kayenta Campground
note: Just outside Arches and Canyonlands, this campground overlooks the Colorado River’s dramatic 2,000-foot cliffs. The sunrise casts a fiery glow over the desert landscape, rivaling the Grand Canyon in grandeur.

name: Juniper Springs Campground
note: Amid Florida’s subtropical wilderness, this campground offers views of crystal-clear springs and ancient cypress trees. The lush greenery and water reflections create a tranquil, unique vista.

name: Houchin Ferry Campground
note: Along the Green River, this site provides scenic river views framed by limestone bluffs and hardwood forests. The rolling hills hint at the vast cave system below.

name: Savanna Portage State Park Campground
note: East of the Mississippi in northern Minnesota, this campground overlooks shimmering lakes surrounded by dense woods. The peaceful water views and vibrant autumn colors stand out.

name: Davidson River Campground
note: Near the Blue Ridge Parkway, this campground features views of rugged Appalachian peaks and cascading waterfalls like Looking Glass Falls. The dense forest adds depth to the landscape.

name: Cranberry Lake Campground
note: Set in the heart of the Adirondacks, this spot offers serene lake views framed by forested peaks. The reflection of mountains in the water creates a pristine wilderness scene.

name: Elkmont Campground
note: Surrounded by misty ridges and lush forests, this site delivers breathtaking views of the Smokies’ rolling peaks. The elevation and vibrant fall foliage amplify the scenery.

name: Weiser State Forest (Halderman Tract) Campsite H4 Tract)
